I had three people message, unprompted, encouraging me to watch #AnatomyOfAFall. It's a brilliant film and undoubtedly deserves the Cannes Palme d’Or and the five Oscar nods. But like any meaningful experience, it's taken more than a few weeks to understand how this film managed to imprint itself. What I most appreciated about #AnatomyOfAFall is how it uses death and a courtroom trial to show just how impossible it is for us to convey the truth of a relationship to anyone who is outside of it. A wife's husband dies. She is left alone to represent the truth of what their relationship was. At first it feels like she tries to give his truth as much weight as her own. And this seems to be a continuation of what she represented in their relationship. In fact, if we were looking at why they were together, rather than how he died, it's clear that her unrelenting search for truth was something that he loved or needed - despite the affairs, mistakes and betrayals. But maintaining this complex representation to an outside audience, let alone a courtroom weighing your guilt or innocence, becomes close to impossible. In the post-mortem, her independence and search for truth is now conveyed as a cold honesty, a selfishness where she continually put her needs above her husbands. Her lawyer practically begs her to reduce their relationship to a single narrative, to only her truth, so as to help in her defence. But she seems to be unable to. Why? Perhaps this would break with who she knows herself to be and so be worse than any conviction. Perversely, while this shows an undeniable strength of character, it's left to her young son to wrestle with the implications that come from not wanting to play by the rules: by refusing to reduce the complexity of their "living" relationship into narrative required for how it ended - she leaves it up to the courtroom (aka us) to judge her. Her son grasps the perils of this in a way that she refuses to. I guess in summary this film would've been more aptly titled an Anatomy of a Marriage - the "Fall" is just a hook. I'm curious to hear what your takeaways are. For a way more thorough and thoughtful review I'll pop the good.film guide in the comments.
